details.title: On some recent modifications of Weibull distribution
details.standardTitle: On some recent modifications of Weibull distribution

p: Saralees Nadarajah is an Associate Professor in the Department of Statistics, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, USA. His research interests include climate modeling, extreme value theory, distribution theory, information theory, sampling & experimental designs, and reliability. He is an author/co-author of four books, and has over 230 papers published or accepted. He has held positions in Florida, California, and England.

authors.affiliation: Univ. of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA
authors.name: S. Nadarajah

p: Samuel Kotz is Distinguished Professor of Statistics in the Department of Engineering Management and Systems Engineering, George Washington University, Washington, D.C., USA. He is the senior co-editor-in-chief of the thirteen-volume Encyclopedia of Statistical Sciences, an author or coauthor of over 300 papers on statistical methodology & theory, 25 books in the field of statistics and quality control, three Russian-English scientific dictionaries, and coauthor of the often-cited Compendium of Statistical Distributions.

details.abstract: Since the turn of the century, several papers have appeared in reliability journals (including the IEEE Transactions on Reliability) which claim to have proposed new modifications of the traditional Weibull distribution. It is pointed out here that the proposed distributions are either not new, or arise from a representation suggested by Gurvich et al. . A modification is suggested that contains all of the proposed distributions as particular cases.

citations.title: On some recent modifications of Weibull distribution

context.text: [1] considered a class of distributions generalizing the traditional Weibull distribution.
[1])where \$G(t)\$ is a monotonically increasing function of \$t\$ with the only limitation \$G(t)\geq 0\$.
[1] provided a detailed treatment of (1) by taking \$G(t)=t^{\beta}\exp(bt)\$, which gives the form (equivalent to their (10))Gurvich et al.
[1] derived formulas for the pdf, and the moments of (2); and also discussed estimation procedures for its parameters.

[1] is not cited, Xie et al. [3] (see also Tang et al. [4], and Wu et al. [5]) claim to have introduced a new class of distributions given by the cdf ((1) in their paper)This is a particular case of the model given by (1), when \$G(t)=\exp(t/\alpha)^{\beta}-1\$.

[1]) which belong to the class given by (1) include

•the log Weibull distribution due to White [8] given by the cdf for \$-\infty<t<\infty\$, \$-\infty<a<\infty\$, and \$b>0\$.
[1] is recognized by the general audience of reliability journals.

references.text: M. R. Gurvich, A. T. Dibenedetto, S. V. Rande, "A new statistical distribution for characterizing the random strength of brittle materials", Journal of Materials Science, vol. 32, pp. 2559-2564, 1997.

links.abstract: A new lifetime distribution capable of modeling a bathtub-shaped hazard-rate function is proposed. The proposed model is derived as a limiting case of the Beta Integrated Model and has both the Weibull distribution and Type 1 extreme value distribution as special cases. The model can be considered as another useful 3-parameter generalization of the Weibull distribution. An advantage of the model is that the model parameters can be estimated easily based on a Weibull probability paper (WPP) plot ...

[2], Xie et al. [3], and Chen [6] have overlooked an important work.

context.text: Chen [6] claims to have introduced a new class of distributions given by the cdf Again, this is a particular case of the model given by (1).
This would contain the models due to Lai et al. [2], Xie et al. [3], and Chen [6] as particular cases (see Section II).
This would also help to acknowledge the fact that the papers by Lai et al. [2], Xie et al. [3], and Chen [6] have overlooked an important work.
